Got a Question
Scottish university tuition fee levels are to rise from 2006
column3: eligible Scottish-domiciled students and EU students will continue to have their fees paid for them by the Student Awards Agency for Scotland (SAAS) and will therefore be unaffected by the changes that are to be introduced.  Students who started their course prior to 2006 and all self-funding students ordinarily resident in Scotland (ie those who do not have their fees paid for them by SAAS) will continue to pay fees at their current rates
column4: rather than the increased levels proposed.

column1: Applications from Scottish and EU students for fee support must be made to the Student Awards Agency for Scotland (SAAS) each academic year. Forms are available from the University in mid April or by telephoning SAAS.  It is also recommended that where possible applications should be made on line. (See useful contacts).

The Graduate Endowment is a fixed amount that some graduates will have to pay at the end of their degree if they receive a degree or if they meet the requirements for an award. It applies to Scottish domiciled students and EU students who started their first full-time degree course at a Scottish institution on or after 1 August 2001. The Education (Graduate Endowment and Student Support) (Scotland) Act 2001 provides for the Graduate Endowment.
Students have to pay the Graduate Endowment in recognition of the higher education benefits they have received. The funds will go towards student support for future generations.
Although graduates do not pay the endowment until the April after they have completed their course
column2: the amount to be paid is set at the beginning of their degree course. The fixed amounts are set when you start your course.  The Student Loan Company will be offering loans to help with the repayments.

column1: If you are under 25 when you start your course
column2: eligible for help with your tuition fees
column4: not an independent student and are taking a full-time course you will be eligible to apply to SAAS for this bursary (YSB).

column1: By taking the level of your family’s income below
column2: you should be able to work out your entitlement to this allowance.

column1: If you are eligible for the Young Students' Bursary
column2: this will replace part of your loan support. Incomes over £31
column3: 000 do not qualify for the Young Students’ Bursary.  The YSB is to be paid in monthly instalments from September 2006.

column1: You may be entitled to this grant if you are single
column3: divorced or separated and bringing up children on your own.  Written evidence of your lone parent status is required every year you make an application.  The lone parent grant is paid direct to your bank account in 3 instalments at the start of each term.

column1: Additional Childcare Grant for Lone Parents

If you are in receipt of the Lone Parents’ Grant then you will also be eligible for the childcare grant if you have registered or formal childcare costs to meet.  A separate application will be sent once you have advised SAAS that you wish to claim this additional award.  Childcare grants will also be paid direct to your bank account in 3 instalments at the start of each term.
You can only claim this grant for your husband or wife if you are legally married to them
column2: although you cannot claim this grant for your student spouse. This grant is means tested on taxable incomes.  The dependants’ grant is paid direct to your bank account in 3 instalments at the start of each term.

column1: If you were previously in care before commencing your full time studies then you may be eligible to claim this grant. Grants of up to £100 can be given to help with accommodation costs over the summer months.

This is a means tested grant that is paid in term 2. To claim for travel expenses application forms are available on line at www.saas.gov.uk from December.  Forms can also be downloaded from this site and are also available in Student Services.  SAAS will only pay the cheapest fares available and you are expected to pay the first £155.
If you are suffering financial hardship during the first term and you have dependants or high travelling expenses
column2: you may apply for an early payment of 50% of your expenses.  Requests for advance payments must be made in writing outlining details of your financial circumstances and how much you spend on travel every week/month.

column1: If your claim for travel expenses is successful it will be paid direct into your bank account within 28 days of submitting your application.

The University has introduced Opportunity Bursaries for 1st year students who can demonstrate good academic achievement.  Bursaries of £500 will be awarded to those students who can satisfy the criterion.  For further details on these bursaries please contact Student Services.
The Carnegie Trust for the Universities of Scotland

For Scottish students studying at a Scottish University towards a first degree and do not qualify for free tuition fees. The Trust offers fee assistance for students who are not eligible for assistance from SAAS.
Write for an application form to: The Carnegie Trust

From September 2006 universities in the UK outside of Scotland will be allowed to vary the fees they charge new students.   However students applying to this institution and who are resident in England
column2: Wales or Northern Ireland will be charged £1700.  It is proposed that students from low-income backgrounds may be eligible for bursaries of £300.  Further details will be available in May 2006.

column1: From September 2006 eligiblefull-time undergraduate students will not have to pay fees beforetheystartuniversity or whilst they are studying.  Instead eligible students will be able to applyfor a Student Loan for Fees to cover these costs. This means that they won't have to find the money before they start their course or whilst they are studying
column2: and thefeeswill be paid direct to the university on their behalf. Students will repay these loans once they have left university and are earning over £15

column1: The new Maintenance Grant will replace the HE Grant.  Students with household incomes of £17
column3: independent students) will receive the full £2
column4: 700 Maintenance Grant. Students with household incomes above £17
column6: with a minimum grant of £50 payable once household income reaches £37

column2: students starting their full-time course on or after 1 September 2006 will be eligible for the new student support package.

column1: The amount of student loan you receive depends upon where you live while you study and for the majority of students - your household/parental income.

Student loans are available for full-time study to those under 55.  If you are aged 50–55 at the start of your course you will be asked to confirm that you intend to return to work on completion of your course.  The table below shows the maximum maintenance loans available to eligible undergraduate ‘home’ students in 2006.
Student living away from home
You can obtain a student loan even if you have previously studied in higher education.  However
column2: there may be some difficulties if you have an old style student loan and have not kept up to date with your deferments.

column1: This fund provides for those students who have a disability or learning difficulty and incur extra expenses by attending either a full-time or part-time undergraduate course or a full-time postgraduate course
column2: which is funded by the Student Awards Agency for Scotland.  Money can be given for specialist equipment
column3: non-medical helper and in some cases an additional amount for travel costs.

column1: Students do not have to take out the student loan to be eligible for this support.  Currently Scottish students who have been awarded DSA  - at any point in their University career - do not have to pay back the Graduate Endowment on successful completion of their course
If you cannot get financial support from other sources you may be eligible to get a Career Development Loan (CDL).  You must be over 18
column2: studying in the UK and wishing to apply for no more than 80% of your course fees plus other costs
column4: 000.  If you have been out of work for 3 months or more you may be able to apply for 100% course fees.

column1: Your course must not last longer than two years
column2: and the government will pay the interest in the first year only.  You will have to start repaying the CDL one month after you finish your course
column3: if you are unemployed on completion of your course you will be given up to 17 months grace for deferment.

column1: Application forms are available from the Student Finance Advisor (see useful contacts).  Further information can be obtained from:www.lifelonglearning.dfes.gov.uk/cdl.
As part of the Financial Support package available to students
column2: the Government has given money known as Hardship Funds to institutions to help provide financial assistance to students whose access to higher education might be inhibited by financial considerations or who face financial difficulties in completing their studies.

applications will be means tested and financial and family circumstances will be taken into account.  There will be a maximum overall limit of award for each student and the amount awarded will be at the discretion of the Fund Administrator.  Hardship Funds cannot be used to help students meet the cost of their tuition fees. Application forms are available in Student Services from September.

column1: The Childcare Fund is also part of the financial support package available to eligible students and is administered along with the Hardship Fund.  Students who have both Childcare and Hardship needs may be eligible to access support from both the Childcare Fund and the Hardship Fund.

This fund provides assistance with the cost of formal childcare expenses only.  Undergraduate full-time students only will be eligible.  Postgraduate and part-time students will be considered for formal childcare from the Hardship Fund.  Applications for childcare will be given priority and will be paid direct to the childcare provider on a termly basis.

If you have not received your student funding you can apply to the University for a short-term advance.  An Advance can be made available to students who have not yet received their Student Loan in Term 1.   These advances are given on the understanding that they will be repaid when you receive your student funding.  However
column2: some students may have their advance made into an Award on full submission of documents and completion of a Financial Support application form.

column1: Contact Student Services if you have not received your student funding at the start of term.
The University operates a number of trusts on behalf of the trustees and further information on these trusts and how to apply is available from the Student Finance Advisor. (See useful contacts).
Useful Contacts at University of Abertay Dundee
For further information on any or all aspects of being a student please contact:
You can read more information about student finance and the correct points of contact here.
• Student Awards Agency for Scotland (SAAS) (Scotland & EU)
